title: Reproducing a 1989 Neural Network Paper in 2022
excerpt: Can we improve on a 33-year-old neural network paper using modern deep learning techniques? An exploration of progress in deep learning through reproduction.
content:
Introduction

The Yann LeCun et al. (1989) paper 'Backpropagation Applied to Handwritten Zip Code Recognition' is of historical significance because it is, to my knowledge, the earliest real-world application of a neural net trained end-to-end with backpropagation.

I set out to reproduce this paper to understand the nature of progress in deep learning over the past 33 years.

The Original Architecture

The original network consisted of:

  • 256 input units (16x16 grayscale images)
  • Layer H1: 768 hidden units (12 x 64)
  • Layer H2: 192 hidden units (12 x 16)
  • Layer H3: 30 hidden units
  • 10 output units (one for each digit)

Original Results vs Modern Reproduction

The original paper reported:

eval: split train. loss 2.5e-3. error 0.14%. misses: 10
eval: split test . loss 1.8e-2. error 5.00%. misses: 102

My training script in its current form prints at the end of the 23rd pass:

eval: split train. loss 4.073383e-03. error 0.62%. misses: 45
eval: split test . loss 2.838382e-02. error 4.09%. misses: 82

Key Learnings

Despite 33 years of progress, the improvements are more incremental than revolutionary. The original paper's architecture and approach remain remarkably effective.

What Changed?

  • Better optimization algorithms (Adam vs SGD)
  • Improved initialization techniques
  • Regularization methods (dropout, batch normalization)
  • More efficient GPU utilization

Conclusion

This exercise demonstrates that while we've made significant progress in deep learning, the fundamental principles established in 1989 remain sound. The real progress has been in our ability to scale these techniques to larger datasets and more complex problems.

title: Getting Started with Python: A Beginner's Guide
excerpt: Everything you need to know to start your Python programming journey, from installation to writing your first programs.
content:
Why Python?

Python is one of the most popular programming languages in the world, and for good reason. It's:

  • Easy to learn and read
  • Versatile (web dev, data science, AI, automation)
  • Has a huge community and ecosystem
  • Great for beginners and professionals alike

Installing Python

First, you'll need to install Python on your system:

Windows

  1. Download Python from python.org
  2. Run the installer
  3. Check 'Add Python to PATH'
  4. Click 'Install Now'

Linux (Ubuntu/Debian)

sudo apt update
sudo apt install python3 python3-pip

Your First Python Program

Let's write the classic 'Hello World' program:

print('Hello, World!')

Save this as hello.py and run it:

python hello.py

Variables and Data Types

Python has several built-in data types:

# Numbers
age = 25
pi = 3.14159

# Strings
name = 'Kanchana'
greeting = 'Hello, World!'

# Booleans
is_student = True
is_graduated = False

# Lists
fruits = ['apple', 'banana', 'orange']

# Dictionaries
person = {
    'name': 'Kanchana',
    'age': 25,
    'job': 'Developer'
}

Control Flow

If Statements

temperature = 25

if temperature > 30:
    print('It\'s hot!')
elif temperature > 20:
    print('It\'s warm!')
else:
    print('It\'s cold!')

Loops

# For loop
for i in range(5):
    print(f'Number: {i}')

# While loop
count = 0
while count < 5:
    print(f'Count: {count}')
    count += 1

Functions

def greet(name):
    return f'Hello, {name}!'

def add_numbers(a, b):
    return a + b

# Using functions
message = greet('Kanchana')
print(message)  # Hello, Kanchana!

result = add_numbers(5, 3)
print(result)  # 8

Next Steps

Now that you know the basics, here are some great next steps:

  • Build small projects (calculator, todo list, etc.)
  • Learn about modules and packages
  • Explore web frameworks like Flask or Django
  • Dive into data science with pandas and NumPy
  • Try automation with scripts
The best way to learn programming is by doing. Start building things, make mistakes, and learn from them!

title: Building a Windows 95 Themed Portfolio
excerpt: How I created a fully functional Windows 95 interface using only HTML, CSS, and vanilla JavaScript.
content:
The Inspiration

I wanted my portfolio to stand out. Instead of going with the typical modern design, I decided to recreate the nostalgia of Windows 95.

Core Features

  • Draggable windows with minimize/maximize/close buttons
  • Working taskbar with clock
  • Start menu with program launcher
  • MS-DOS prompt with actual commands
  • Desktop icons with selection
  • Windows Media Player with playlist

Technical Implementation

Window System

The window system uses vanilla JavaScript:

function startDrag(event, windowId) {
    draggedWindow = document.getElementById(windowId);
    setActiveWindow(windowId);
    
    const rect = draggedWindow.getBoundingClientRect();
    dragOffsetX = event.clientX - rect.left;
    dragOffsetY = event.clientY - rect.top;
}

Styling

Recreating the Windows 95 aesthetic required attention to detail:

.window {
    background: #c0c0c0;
    border: 2px solid;
    border-color: #dfdfdf #000000 #000000 #dfdfdf;
    box-shadow: 2px 2px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.2);
}

Key Learnings

Building this portfolio taught me that constraints breed creativity. Working within the Windows 95 design system forced me to think differently about UI/UX.

This project proves you don't need the latest frameworks to build something impressive!
